user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_driver:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_driver(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				    struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	char command[256];
	int ret;

	ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	/* Try probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* Try sudo probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "sudo modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* If all else fails... */
	return ldrv->sdrv ? 0 : -ENODEV;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_probe_driver:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function metal_linux_probe_driver and the related macro. There are no calls to memcmp anywhere in the supplied code or macro definition. The code uses snprintf, system, sysfs_open_driver and the metal_log macro, none of which contain or invoke memcmp in the shown fragments. Because MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 specifically concerns use of the Standard Library function memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, there are no code fragments here that need investigation for that rule. (Any memcmp usage inside externally referenced functions such as sysfs_open_driver or library/system implementations is outside the provided code and thus not part of this analysis.)
